This is a list of Nobel Prize laureates by country. Listings for *Economics* refer to the related Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Sciences. The Nobel Prizes and the Prize in Economic Sciences have been awarded 567 times to 889 recipients, of which 26 awards (all Peace Prizes) were to organizations. Due to some recipients receiving multiple awards, the total number of recipients is 860 individuals and 22 organizations.[1]


The present list ranks laureates under the country/countries that are stated by the Nobel Prize committee on its website.[2] The list does not distinguish between laureates who received a full prize and the majority who shared a prize.[3] Some laureates are listed under more than one country, because the official website mentions multiple countries in relation to the laureate.[4] If a country is merely mentioned as the place of birth, an asterisk (\*) is used in the respective listing to indicate this.[5] In this case, the birth country is mentioned in *italics* at the other listings of this laureate.


Organizations are listed here if the Nobel Prize committee relates them to a single country.[6]

22. **^** Disputed territory with undetermined political status. Administration is split between Morocco and the Sahrawi Arab Democratic Republic, both of which claim the entire territory. The Sahrawi Arab Democratic Republic's administrative control is limited to approximately 20% of the territory, with the remaining 80% of the territory occupied by Morocco (see Western Sahara conflict).
23. **^** Listed as *![](image) Bonaire*, *![](image) Sint Eustatius* and *![](image) Saba*.
24. **^** Including *![](image) Saint Helena*, *![](image) Ascension*, and *![](image) Tristan da Cunha*.

## References[edit]


1. **^** "UNSD — Methodology". *unstats.un.org*.
2. **^** "World Population Prospects, 2023 Revision". United Nations Department of Economic and Social Affairs, Population Division, Population Estimates and Projections Section. 11 July 2022. Retrieved 10 February 2023.
3. **^** "Total population, both sexes combined (thousands)". *UNdata*. United Nations Statistics Division. 11 July 2022. Retrieved 10 February 2023.
4. ^ ***a*** ***b*** "Definition of Regions". *World Population Prospects, the 2019 Revision*. United Nations Department of Economic and Social Affairs, Population Division, Population Estimates and Projections Section. June 2019. Archived from the original on 8 September 2018. Retrieved 17 June 2019.
